awd_titl_txt: Collaborative REU Site: Examining the Intersection of Food, Housing and Healthcare
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is funded from the Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Sites program in the SBE Directorate. It has both scientific and societal benefits, and integrates research and education. This REU site is a collaboration among three different academic institutions, Davidson College (DC), Johnson C. Smith (JCSU), and University of North Carolina-Charlotte (UNCC). The goal of the REU and the ongoing project is to provide training in social science methods to undergraduates and to generate original research exploring differential access to food, housing, and healthcare in underserved neighborhoods northwest Charlotte. The project places students in research settings alongside faculty members and key community players to define and creatively address social problems. Students who take part in this REU will enhance their research skills to identify the sources and mechanisms that reproduce social inequities. This REU will focus on the methods of studying differential access to food, housing, and healthcare as important indicators of historically and socially rooted inequalities. The intellectual focus of the REU will be to define access as both an outcome of historical and social processes and as a contribution to ongoing and future disparities.  

We expect this REU will help students build scholarship by learning how to plan and conduct research and share their results with academic and public audiences, including through a planned edited volume that includes student work. We will also work with students to show them how to engage with policymakers and community partners through communication tools like memos and policy briefs. Students will also have the opportunity to learn about how to engage with issues of access through social entrepreneurship through work with the Centers for Innovation and Entrepreneurship at all three academic institutions. Students will be able to pursue interests in public humanities through creative approaches to public outreach at the end of the summer. In all these ways, faculty, student, and community partner teams will be able to share valuable research about the value and immediate applicability of social science research on access to food, housing, and healthcare to community organizations and the general public.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) project provided training in social science methods to undergraduate students for exploring differential access to food, housing, and healthcare as important indicators of historically and socially rooted inequalities in underserved neighborhoods in Charlotte, North Carolina (Mecklenburg County).  The project encouraged students to draw on their classroom experiences to work alongside graduate students and faculty members to define and creatively address social problems in the neighborhoods within the Charlotte community.  Similarly, students who took part in this REU enhanced their research skills as they carefully identified the sources and mechanisms that ensured the reproduction of social inequities through Redlining.   

The REU project focused on the methods of studying differential access to food, housing, and healthcare as important indicators of historically and socially rooted inequalities through redlining. Participating students investigated one of the three focus areas and used discussions about the other two foci to help understand cross-cutting relationships between them. The objective was to equip the students with the history and the contemporary implications of redlining.  Most importantly, how people perceived and actualized access to what they needed regarding these three domains.  Each research team used historical and geo-spatial data, ArcGIS StoryMaps, to answer their research question(s).  These research questions stemmed from exploring various data sets such as community gardens and food bank locations, the distance and quality of health facilities, and the impact of air pollution, as well as crime rates, on preterm births in Mecklenburg County, Charlotte, NC. 

Through ArcGIS StoryMaps, students, of diverse backgrounds and abilities, were able to introduce topics through their scope of view as well as transform relative information (personal experiences) to physical places.  Students were able to complete field data off-site and communicate those discoveries in real-time.  The ARcGIS mapping results showed that food access within the city of Charlotte is intensely tied to the demographics of a given neighborhood's composition: race/ethnicity, income levels, and even recipiency of federal programs like SNAP are directly correlated to the likelihood of a given area having better or worse access to different types of food.  ArcGIS mapping results also indicated that Mecklenburg was not among the counties with the highest rate of live, preterm births. However, Mecklenburg County, along with 36 other counties, recorded 10.5% to 11.7% of live births being preterm in recent years. 

The goal of the REU and the ongoing project was to combine the notion of redlining with differential access to food, housing, and healthcare in underserved neighborhoods in Charlotte, North Carolina and express these finding through GIS mapping.  Students built scholarship by crafting research questions, investigating them, and sharing their results with academic and public audiences, including planned edited volume that included student work (e.g., undergraduate student oral presentation at the 77th Annual Meeting of Beta Kappa Chi & the National Institute of Science).  The future use of Story Maps could provide a new mode of research collaboration in developing further analysis in defining and addressing comparable socially determined community health issues in other communities including those surrounding Charlotte, NC (Mecklenburg, County).
